FUNCTION revpos(p, q) RESULT(newpos)
  INTEGER, DIMENSION(0:1), INTENT(IN) :: p, q
  INTEGER :: tmp
  INTEGER, DIMENSION(0:1) :: newpos
  INTEGER :: vec(0:1)
  vec(0) = p(0) - q(0)
  vec(1) = p(1) - q(1)
  tmp = vec(0)
  vec(0) = vec(1)
  vec(1) = -tmp
  newpos(0) = q(0) + vec(0)
  newpos(1) = q(1) + vec(1)
END FUNCTION revpos

FUNCTION revpos(p, q) RESULT( newpos ) INTEGER, DIMENSION(0:1), INTENT(IN) :: p, q

  INTEGER, DIMENSION(0:1) :: newpos

  INTEGER :: tmp, vec(0:1)

  vec(0) = p(0) - q(0)

  vec(1) = p(1) - q(1)

  tmp = vec(0)

  vec(0) = vec(1)

  vec(1) = -tmp

  newpos(0) = q(0) + vec(0)

  newpos(1) = q(1) + vec(1)

END FUNCTION revpos

Translating this to Fortran requires understanding how to handle arrays, functions, and input/output in Fortran compared to Java.

FUNCTION revpos(p, q) RESULT(newpos)
  INTEGER, DIMENSION(0:1), INTENT(IN) :: p, q
  INTEGER :: tmp
  INTEGER, DIMENSION(0:1) :: newpos
  INTEGER :: vec(0:1)
  vec(0) = p(0) - q(0)
  vec(1) = p(1) - q(1)
  tmp = vec(0)
  vec(0) = vec(1)
  vec(1) = -tmp
  newpos(0) = q(0) + vec(0)
  newpos(1) = q(1) + vec(1)
END FUNCTION revpos

First, the function revpos:

FUNCTION revpos(p, q) RESULT( newpos )

  INTEGER, DIMENSION(0:1), INTENT(IN) :: p, q

  INTEGER, DIMENSION(0:1) :: newpos

  INTEGER :: tmp, vec(0:1)

  vec(0) = p(0) - q(0)

  vec(1) = p(1) - q(1)

  tmp = vec(0)

  vec(0) = vec(1)

  vec(1) = -tmp

  newpos(0) = q(0) + vec(0)

  newpos(1) = q(1) + vec(1)

END FUNCTION revpos

Wait the function returns newpos which is an array. To make this an internal function, place it inside the program.

Now, in the program:

program atcoder_ABC108_B

implicit none

integer, dimension(0:3) :: input

integer, dimension(0:3,0:1) :: position

integer, dimension(0:3) :: output

integer :: temp(0:1)

! Function revpos defined here

contains

  FUNCTION revpos(p, q) RESULT( newpos )

    integer, dimension(0:1), intent(in) :: p, q

    integer, dimension(0:1) :: newpos

    integer, dimension(0:1) :: vec

    integer :: tmp

    vec = p - q  ! Subtraction

    tmp = vec(0)

    newpos(0) = vec(1)  ! moved to new variable for clarity?

    vec(0) = vec(1)

    vec(1) = -tmp

    newpos = q + vec

    ! or step-by-step:

    ! But let me see:

    vec(0) = p(0) - q(0)

    vec(1) = p(1) - q(1)

    tmp = vec(0)

    vec(0) = vec(1)

    vec(1) = -tmp

    newpos(0) = q(0) + vec(0)

    newpos(1) = q(1) + vec(1)

  END FUNCTION revpos

  

! Start of main code

  read(*,*) input(0), input(1), input(2), input(3)

  ! Initialize position

  position(0,0) = input(0)

  position(0,1) = input(1)

  position(1,0) = input(2)

  position(1,1) = input(3)

  ! compute positions 2 and 3:

  position(2,:) = revpos( position(0,:), position(1,:) )

  position(3,:) = revpos( position(1,:), position(2,:) )

  ! check condition:

  temp = revpos( position(2,:), position(3,:) )

  if( position(0,0) == temp(0) .AND. position(0,1) == temp(1) ) then

      print *, "OK"

  end if

  ! set output array

  output(0) = position(2,0)

  output(1) = position(2,1)

  output(2) = position(3,0)

  output(3) = position(3,1)

  ! print output

  print *, output(0)

  print *, output(1)

  print *, output(2)

  print *, output(3)

end program atcoder_ABC108_B
